options.description: <para>The default search engine used in the address bar and search bar.</para>
options.title: programs.firefox.profiles.<name>.search.default

options.description:
<para>Attribute set of search engine configurations. Engines
that only have <varname>metaData</varname> specified will
be treated as builtin to Firefox.
</para><para>
See <link xlink:href=
"https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/669329e284f8e8e2bb28090617192ca9b4ef3380/toolkit/components/search/SearchEngine.jsm#1138-1177">SearchEngine.jsm</link>
in Firefox's source for available options. We maintain a
mapping to let you specify all options in the referenced
link without underscores, but it may fall out of date with
future options.
</para><para>
Note, <varname>icon</varname> is also a special option
added by Home Manager to make it convenient to specify
absolute icon paths.</para>
options.type: attribute set of attribute set of (JSON value)
options.title: programs.firefox.profiles.<name>.search.engines

options.description:
<para>Whether to force replace the existing search
configuration. This is recommended since Firefox will
replace the symlink for the search configuration on every
launch, but note that you'll lose any existing
configuration by enabling this.</para>

options.description:
<para>The order the search engines are listed in. Any engines
that aren't included in this list will be listed after
these in an unspecified order.</para>
options.title: programs.firefox.profiles.<name>.search.order

options.description:
<para>Attribute set of Firefox preferences.

Firefox only supports int, bool, and string types for
preferences, but home-manager will automatically
convert all other JSON-compatible values into strings.</para>
options.type: attribute set of (Firefox preference (int, bool, string, and also attrs, list, float as a JSON string))

options.description: <para>Whether to enable gitui, blazing fast terminal-ui for git written in rust.</para>
options.title: programs.gitui.enable

options.description: <para>The package to use.</para>
options.title: programs.gitui.package

options.description:
<para>Key config in Ron file format. This is written to
<filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/gitui/key_config.ron</filename>.</para>
options.example:
''
  exit: Some(( code: Char('c'), modifiers: ( bits: 2,),)),
  quit: Some(( code: Char('q'), modifiers: ( bits: 0,),)),
  exit_popup: Some(( code: Esc, modifiers: ( bits: 0,),)),
''
options.title: programs.gitui.keyConfig

options.default:
''
  (
    selected_tab: Reset,
    command_fg: White,
    selection_bg: Blue,
    selection_fg: White,
    cmdbar_bg: Blue,
    cmdbar_extra_lines_bg: Blue,
    disabled_fg: DarkGray,
    diff_line_add: Green,
    diff_line_delete: Red,
    diff_file_added: LightGreen,
    diff_file_removed: LightRed,
    diff_file_moved: LightMagenta,
    diff_file_modified: Yellow,
    commit_hash: Magenta,
    commit_time: LightCyan,
    commit_author: Green,
    danger_fg: Red,
    push_gauge_bg: Blue,
    push_gauge_fg: Reset,
    tag_fg: LightMagenta,
    branch_fg: LightYellow,
  )
''

options.description:
<para>If <literal>true</literal>, allow applications in the
terminal to make text boldface.</para>
options.title: programs.gnome-terminal.profile.<name>.allowBold

options.description: <para>Turn on/off the terminal's bell.</para>
options.title: programs.gnome-terminal.profile.<name>.audibleBell

options.description:
<para>Which string the terminal should send to an application when the user
presses the <emphasis>Backspace</emphasis> key.

<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>auto</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Attempt to determine the right value from the terminal's IO settings.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>ascii-backspace</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send an ASCII backspace character (0x08).
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>ascii-delete</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send an ASCII delete character (0x7F).
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>delete-sequence</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send the <quote>@7</quote> control sequence.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>tty</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send terminal’s <quote>erase</quote> setting.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>
options.title: programs.gnome-terminal.profile.<name>.backspaceBinding

options.description: <para>Whether bold text is shown in bright colors.</para>

options.description:
<para>Which string the terminal should send to an application when the user
presses the <emphasis>Delete</emphasis> key.

<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>auto</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send the <quote>@7</quote> control sequence.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>ascii-backspace</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send an ASCII backspace character (0x08).
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>ascii-delete</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send an ASCII delete character (0x7F).
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>delete-sequence</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send the <quote>@7</quote> control sequence.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>tty</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Send terminal’s <quote>erase</quote> setting.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>

options.description: <para>Whether to enable GnuPG.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.enable

options.description: <para>The Gnupg package to use (also used the gpg-agent service).</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.package

options.description: <para>Directory to store keychains and configuration.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.homedir

options.description:
<para>If set to <literal>true</literal>, you may manage your keyring as a user
using the <literal>gpg</literal> command. Upon activation, the keyring
will have managed keys added without overwriting unmanaged keys.
</para><para>
If set to <literal>false</literal>, the path
<filename>$GNUPGHOME/pubring.kbx</filename> will become an immutable
link to the Nix store, denying modifications.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.mutableKeys

options.description:
<para>If set to <literal>true</literal>, you may manage trust as a user using
the <command>gpg</command> command. Upon activation, trusted keys have
their trust set without overwriting unmanaged keys.
</para><para>
If set to <literal>false</literal>, the path
<filename>$GNUPGHOME/trustdb.gpg</filename> will be
<emphasis>overwritten</emphasis> on each activation, removing trust for
any unmanaged keys. Be careful to make a backup of your old
<filename>trustdb.gpg</filename> before switching to immutable trust!</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.mutableTrust

options.description:
<para>A list of public keys to be imported into GnuPG. Note, these key files
will be copied into the world-readable Nix store.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.publicKeys

options.description: <para>Path of an OpenPGP public key file.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.publicKeys.*.source

options.description: <para>Text of an OpenPGP public key.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.publicKeys.*.text

options.description:
<para>The amount of trust you have in the key ownership and the care the
owner puts into signing other keys. The available levels are
<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>unknown</literal> or <literal>1</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>I don't know or won't say.</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>never</literal> or <literal>2</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>I do NOT trust.</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>marginal</literal> or <literal>3</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>I trust marginally.</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>full</literal> or <literal>4</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>I trust fully.</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>ultimate</literal> or <literal>5</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>I trust ultimately.</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist>
</para><para>
See <link xlink:href="https://www.gnupg.org/gph/en/manual/x334.html"/>
for more.</para>
options.title: programs.gpg.publicKeys.*.trust

options.description:

<para>
Note that lists are converted to duplicate keys.</para>

options.description: <para>Commands to be executed on connecting to server.</para>
options.title: programs.hexchat.channels.<name>.commands

options.description:
<para>The login method. The allowed options are:
<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>null</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Default</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"nickServMsg"</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>NickServ (/MSG NickServ + password)</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"nickServ"</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>NickServ (/NICKSERV + password)</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"challengeAuth"</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Challenge Auth (username + password)</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"sasl"</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>SASL (username + password)</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"serverPassword"</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Server password (/PASS password)</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"saslExternal"</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>SASL EXTERNAL (cert)</para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>"customCommands"</literal></term>
    <listitem>
      <para>Use "commands" field for auth. For example
      <programlisting language="nix">
commands = [ "/msg NickServ IDENTIFY my_password" ]
</programlisting>
      </para>
    </listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>
options.title: programs.hexchat.channels.<name>.loginMethod

options.description:
<para>Enables overwriting HexChat configuration files
(<filename>hexchat.conf</filename>, <filename>servlist.conf</filename>).
Any existing HexChat configuration will be lost. Certify to back-up any
previous configuration before enabling this.
</para><para>
Enabling this setting is recommended, because everytime HexChat
application is closed it overwrites Nix/Home Manager provided
configuration files, causing:
<orderedlist numeration="arabic">
  <listitem><para>
    Nix/Home Manager provided configuration to be out of sync with
    actual active HexChat configuration.
  </para></listitem>
  <listitem><para>
    Blocking Nix/Home Manager updates until configuration files are
    manually removed.
  </para></listitem>
</orderedlist></para>
options.title: programs.hexchat.overwriteConfigFiles

token to <filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/nheko/nheko.conf</filename> the
first time we sign in, and we need that data into these settings for the
correct functionality of the application.

authentication stuff into the local database they currently use. Once
this happens, this will no longer be an issue.</para>

[main]

open_cmd = xdg-open

[plugins]
active = git,alias

[[alias]]

[[git]]
quiet = True
manual = False
force_color = False
''

options.description:
<para>Key bindings mapping keys to commands in different modes. This setting
is a dictionary containing mode names and dictionaries mapping keys to
commands: <literal>{mode: {key: command}}</literal> If you want to map
a key to another key, check the <literal>keyMappings</literal> setting
instead. For modifiers, you can use either <literal>-</literal> or
<literal>+</literal> as delimiters, and these names:

<itemizedlist>
  <listitem><para>
    Control: <literal>Control</literal>, <literal>Ctrl</literal>
  </para></listitem>
  <listitem><para>
    Meta: <literal>Meta</literal>, <literal>Windows</literal>,
    <literal>Mod4</literal>
  </para></listitem>
  <listitem><para>
    Alt: <literal>Alt</literal>, <literal>Mod1</literal>
  </para></listitem>
  <listitem><para>
    Shift: <literal>Shift</literal>
  </para></listitem>
</itemizedlist>

For simple keys (no <literal><></literal>-signs), a capital
letter means the key is pressed with Shift. For special keys (with
<literal><></literal>-signs), you need to explicitly add
<literal>Shift-</literal> to match a key pressed with shift. If you
want a binding to do nothing, bind it to the <literal>nop</literal>
command. If you want a default binding to be passed through to the
website, bind it to null. Note that some commands which are only useful
for bindings (but not used interactively) are hidden from the command
completion. See <literal>:</literal>help for a full list of available
commands. The following modes are available:

<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>normal</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Default mode, where most commands are invoked.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>insert</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when an input field is focused on a website, or by
      pressing i in normal mode. Passes through almost all keypresses
      to the website, but has some bindings like
      <literal><Ctrl-e></literal> to open an external editor.
      Note that single keys can’t be bound in this mode.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>hint</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when f is pressed to select links with the keyboard. Note
      that single keys can’t be bound in this mode.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>passthrough</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Similar to insert mode, but passes through all keypresses except
      <literal><Escape></literal> to leave the mode. It might be
      useful to bind <literal><Escape></literal> to some other
      key in this mode if you want to be able to send an Escape key to
      the website as well. Note that single keys can’t be bound in this
      mode.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>command</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when pressing the : key in order to enter a command. Note
      that single keys can’t be bound in this mode.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>prompt</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when there’s a prompt to display, like for download
      locations or when invoked from JavaScript.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>yesno</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when there’s a yes/no prompt displayed.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>caret</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when pressing the v mode, used to select text using the
      keyboard.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>register</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>
      Entered when qutebrowser is waiting for a register name/key for
      commands like <literal>:set-mark</literal>.
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>
options.type: attribute set of attribute set of strings concatenated with " ;; "
options.title: programs.qutebrowser.keyBindings

options.description:
<para>This setting can be used to map keys to other keys. When the key used
as dictionary-key is pressed, the binding for the key used as
dictionary-value is invoked instead. This is useful for global
remappings of keys, for example to map Ctrl-[ to Escape. Note that when
a key is bound (via <literal>bindings.default</literal> or
<literal>bindings.commands</literal>), the mapping is ignored.</para>
options.title: programs.qutebrowser.keyMappings

options.description:
<para>Search engines that can be used via the address bar. Maps a search
engine name (such as <literal>DEFAULT</literal>, or
<literal>ddg</literal>) to a URL with a <literal>{}</literal>
placeholder. The placeholder will be replaced by the search term, use
<literal>{{</literal> and <literal>}}</literal> for literal
<literal>{/}</literal> signs. The search engine named
<literal>DEFAULT</literal> is used when
<literal>url.auto_search</literal> is turned on and something else than
a URL was entered to be opened. Other search engines can be used by
prepending the search engine name to the search term, for example
<literal>:open google qutebrowser</literal>.</para>
options.title: programs.qutebrowser.searchEngines

options.description:

options.description:
<para>At attribute set of Vim settings. The attribute names and
corresponding values must be among the following supported
options.

<informaltable frame="none"><tgroup cols="1"><tbody>
<row>
  <entry><varname>background</varname></entry>
  <entry>one of "dark", "light"</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>backupdir</varname></entry>
  <entry>list of string</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>copyindent</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>directory</varname></entry>
  <entry>list of string</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>expandtab</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>hidden</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>history</varname></entry>
  <entry>signed integer</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>ignorecase</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>modeline</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>mouse</varname></entry>
  <entry>one of "n", "v", "i", "c", "h", "a", "r"</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>mousefocus</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>mousehide</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>mousemodel</varname></entry>
  <entry>one of "extend", "popup", "popup_setpos"</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>number</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>relativenumber</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>shiftwidth</varname></entry>
  <entry>signed integer</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>smartcase</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>tabstop</varname></entry>
  <entry>signed integer</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>undodir</varname></entry>
  <entry>list of string</entry>
</row>

<row>
  <entry><varname>undofile</varname></entry>
  <entry>boolean</entry>
</row>

</tbody></tgroup></informaltable>

See the Vim documentation for detailed descriptions of these
options. Note, use <varname>extraConfig</varname> to
manually set any options not listed above.</para>

options.description: <para>Whether to enable Xmobar, a minimalistic status bar.</para>
options.title: programs.xmobar.enable

options.description: <para>Package providing the <command>xmobar</command> binary.</para>
options.title: programs.xmobar.package

options.description:
<para>Extra configuration lines to add to
<filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/xmobar/.xmobarrc</filename>.
See
<link xlink:href="https://xmobar.org/#configuration" />
for options.</para>
options.example:
Config
  { font        = "Fira Code"
  , borderColor = "#d0d0d0"
  , border      = FullB
  , borderWidth = 3
  , bgColor     = "#222"
  , fgColor     = "grey"
  , position    = TopSize C 99 30
  , commands    =
      [ Run Cpu ["-t", "cpu: <fc=#4eb4fa><bar> <total>%</fc>"] 10
      , Run Network "enp3s0" ["-S", "True", "-t", "eth: <fc=#4eb4fa><rx></fc>/<fc=#4eb4fa><tx></fc>"] 10
      , Run Memory ["-t","mem: <fc=#4eb4fa><usedbar> <usedratio>%</fc>"] 10
      , Run Date "date: <fc=#4eb4fa>%a %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S </fc>" "date" 10
      , Run StdinReader
      ]
  , sepChar     = "%"
  , alignSep    = "}{"
  , template    = "  %StdinReader% | %cpu% | %memory% | %enp3s0%  }{%date%  "
  }
options.title: programs.xmobar.extraConfig

options.description:
<para>Platform theme to use for Qt applications.</para>
<para>The options are
<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>gtk</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Use GTK theme with
      <link xlink:href="https://github.com/qt/qtstyleplugins">qtstyleplugins</link>
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>gnome</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Use GNOME theme with
      <link xlink:href="https://github.com/FedoraQt/QGnomePlatform">qgnomeplatform</link>
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>

relatedPackages.description: QPlatformTheme for a better Qt application inclusion in GNOME
Additional style plugins for Qt5, including BB10, GTK, Cleanlooks, Motif, Plastique

options.title: qt.platformTheme

options.description:
<para>Theme package to be used in Qt5 applications.
Auto-detected from <option>qt.style.name</option> if possible.</para>
options.title: qt.style.package

options.description:
<para>Style to use for Qt5 applications. Case-insensitive.
</para>
<para>Some examples are
<variablelist>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>adwaita</literal></term>
    <term><literal>adwaita-dark</literal></term>
    <term><literal>adwaita-highcontrast</literal></term>
    <term><literal>adwaita-highcontrastinverse</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Use the Adwaita style from
      <link xlink:href="https://github.com/FedoraQt/adwaita-qt">adwaita</link>
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>breeze</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Use the Breeze style from
      <link xlink:href="https://github.com/KDE/breeze">breeze</link>
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
  <varlistentry>
    <term><literal>bb10bright</literal></term>
    <term><literal>bb10dark</literal></term>
    <term><literal>cde</literal></term>
    <term><literal>cleanlooks</literal></term>
    <term><literal>gtk2</literal></term>
    <term><literal>motif</literal></term>
    <term><literal>plastique</literal></term>
    <listitem><para>Use styles from
      <link xlink:href="https://github.com/qt/qtstyleplugins">qtstyleplugins</link>
    </para></listitem>
  </varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>

options.description: <para>Package providing <command>fnott</command>.</para>

options.description:
<para>Path to the configuration file read by fnott.
</para><para>
Note that environment variables in the path won't be properly expanded.
</para><para>
The configuration specified under
<option>services.fnott.settings</option> will be generated and
written to <filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/fnott/fnott.ini</filename>
regardless of this option. This allows using a mutable configuration file
generated from the immutable one, useful in scenarios where live reloading is desired.</para>

<filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/fnott/fnott.ini</filename>.

<citerefentry>

  <manvolnum>5</manvolnum>
</citerefentry> for a list of available options and <link
xlink:href="https://codeberg.org/dnkl/fnott/src/branch/master/fnott.ini"/>
for an example configuration.</para>
options.type: attribute set of attribute set of (INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

<option>pinentry-program</option> in
<filename>gpg-agent.conf</filename>. Beware that
<literal>pinentry-gnome3</literal> may not work on non-Gnome
systems. You can fix it by adding the following to your
system configuration:
<programlisting language="nix">
services.dbus.packages = [ pkgs.gcr ];
</programlisting>
For this reason, the default is <literal>gtk2</literal> for
now.</para>

for more information. The Nix value declared here will be
translated to JSON and written to the <option>rules</option>
key in <filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/grobi.conf</filename>.</para>

instead of a full path. Colon-delimited. This approximates the search
algorithm used by the XDG Icon Theme Specification, but does not
support any of the theme metadata. Therefore, if you want to search
parent themes, you'll need to add them to the path manually.
</para><para>
The <filename>/usr/share/icons/hicolor</filename> and
<filename>/usr/share/pixmaps</filename> directories are
always searched.</para>

and use the one provided by default-timeout instead.</para>

overlay will cause notifications to be displayed above fullscreen
windows, though this may also occur at top depending on your
compositor.</para>

apply margin on all sides. Two comma-separated values will set
vertical and horizontal edges separately. Four comma-separated will
give each edge a separate value.
For example: 10,20,5 will set top margin to 10, left and right to 20
and bottom to five.</para>

body of notifications.</para>

options.description:
<para>How often to run <command>muchsync</command>. This
value is passed to the systemd timer configuration as the
<literal>OnCalendar</literal> option. See
<citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>systemd.time</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>7</manvolnum>
</citerefentry>
for more information about the format.</para>
options.title: services.muchsync.remotes.<name>.frequency

options.description:
<para>Check for locally modified files.
Without this option, muchsync assumes that files in a maildir are
never edited.
</para><para>
<option>checkForModifiedFiles</option> disables certain
optimizations so as to make muchsync at least check the timestamp on
every file, which will detect modified files at the cost of a longer
startup time.
</para><para>
This option is useful if your software regularly modifies the
contents of mail files (e.g., because you are running offlineimap
with "synclabels = yes").</para>
options.title: services.muchsync.remotes.<name>.local.checkForModifiedFiles

options.description:
<para>Whether to begin the synchronisation by running
<command>notmuch new</command> locally.</para>
options.title: services.muchsync.remotes.<name>.local.importNew

options.description:
<para>Check for modified files on the remote side.
Without this option, muchsync assumes that files in a maildir are
never edited.
</para><para>
<option>checkForModifiedFiles</option> disables certain
optimizations so as to make muchsync at least check the timestamp on
every file, which will detect modified files at the cost of a longer
startup time.
</para><para>
This option is useful if your software regularly modifies the
contents of mail files (e.g., because you are running offlineimap
with "synclabels = yes").</para>
options.title: services.muchsync.remotes.<name>.remote.checkForModifiedFiles

options.description:

options.title: services.muchsync.remotes.<name>.remote.importNew

options.description:
<para>Specifies the path to muchsync on the server.
Ordinarily, muchsync should be in the default PATH on the server
so this option is not required.
However, this option is useful if you have to install muchsync in
a non-standard place or wish to test development versions of the
code.</para>
options.title: services.muchsync.remotes.<name>.remote.muchsyncPath

options.description:

options.description:
<para>Polybar configuration. Can be either path to a file, or set of attributes
that will be used to create the final configuration.
See also <option>services.polybar.settings</option> for a more nix-friendly format.</para>
options.type: (attribute set of attribute set of (string or boolean or signed integer or list of string)) or path convertible to it
options.title: services.polybar.config

options.description: <para>Additional configuration to add.</para>
options.example:
''
  [module/date]
  type = internal/date
  interval = 5
  date = "%d.%m.%y"
  time = %H:%M
  format-prefix-foreground = \''${colors.foreground-alt}
  label = %time%  %date%
''
options.title: services.polybar.extraConfig

options.description:
<para>This script will be used to start the polybars.
Set all necessary environment variables here and start all bars.
It can be assumed that <command>polybar</command> executable is in the <envar>PATH</envar>.

Note, this script must start all bars in the background and then terminate.</para>
options.title: services.polybar.script

options.description:
<para>Polybar configuration. This takes a nix attrset and converts it to the
strange data format that polybar uses.
Each entry will be converted to a section in the output file.
Several things are treated specially: nested keys are converted
to dash-separated keys; the special <literal>text</literal> key is ignored as a nested key,
to allow mixing different levels of nesting; and lists are converted to
polybar's <literal>foo-0, foo-1, ...</literal> format.
</para><para>
For example:
<programlisting language="nix">
"module/volume" = {
  type = "internal/pulseaudio";
  format.volume = "<ramp-volume> <label-volume>";
  label.muted.text = "🔇";
  label.muted.foreground = "#666";
  ramp.volume = ["🔈" "🔉" "🔊"];
  click.right = "pavucontrol &";
}
</programlisting>
becomes:
<programlisting language="ini">
[module/volume]
type=internal/pulseaudio
format-volume=<ramp-volume> <label-volume>
label-muted=🔇
label-muted-foreground=#666
ramp-volume-0=🔈
ramp-volume-1=🔉
ramp-volume-2=🔊
click-right=pavucontrol &
</programlisting></para>
options.title: services.polybar.settings

options.description: <para>Whether to enable xcape.</para>
options.title: services.xcape.enable

options.description:
<para>The value has the grammar <literal>Key[|OtherKey]</literal>.
</para>
<para>
The list of key names is found in the header file
<filename>X11/keysymdef.h</filename> (remove the
<literal>XK_</literal> prefix). Note that due to limitations
of X11 shifted keys must be specified as a shift key
followed by the key to be pressed rather than the actual
name of the character. For example to generate "{" the
expression <literal>Shift_L|bracketleft</literal> could be
used (assuming that you have a key with "{" above "[").
</para>
<para>
You can also specify keys in decimal (prefix #), octal (#0),
or hexadecimal (#0x). They will be interpreted as keycodes
unless no corresponding key name is found.</para>

options.description:
<para>A set of named specialized configurations. These can be used to extend
your base configuration with additional settings. For example, you can
have specializations named <quote>light</quote> and <quote>dark</quote>
that applies light and dark color theme configurations.

</para><para>

Note, this is an experimental option for now and you therefore have to
activate the specialization by looking up and running the activation
script yourself. Note, running the activation script will create a new
Home Manager generation.

</para><para>

For example, to activate the <quote>dark</quote> specialization. You can
first look up your current Home Manager generation by running

<programlisting language="console">
  $ home-manager generations | head -1
  2022-05-02 22:49 : id 1758 -> /nix/store/jy…ac-home-manager-generation
</programlisting>

then run

<programlisting language="console">
  $ /nix/store/jy…ac-home-manager-generation/specialization/dark/activate
  Starting Home Manager activation
  …
</programlisting>

</para><para>

WARNING! Since this option is experimental, the activation process may
change in backwards incompatible ways.</para>
options.title: specialization

options.description: <para>Arbitrary Home Manager configuration settings.</para>

options.description:

</citerefentry>.</para>

options.description:
<para>Whether new or changed services that are wanted by active targets
should be started. Additionally, stop obsolete services from the
previous generation.
</para><para>
The alternatives are
<variablelist>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>suggest</literal> (or <literal>false</literal>)</term>
  <listitem><para>
    Use a very simple shell script to print suggested
    <command>systemctl</command> commands to run. You will have to
    manually run those commands after the switch.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>legacy</literal> (or <literal>true</literal>)</term>
  <listitem><para>
    Use a Ruby script to, in a more robust fashion, determine the
    necessary changes and automatically run the
    <command>systemctl</command> commands.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
<varlistentry>
  <term><literal>sd-switch</literal></term>
  <listitem><para>
    Use sd-switch, a third party application, to perform the service
    updates. This tool offers more features while having a small
    closure size. Note, it requires a fully functional user D-Bus
    session. Once tested and deemed sufficiently robust, this will
    become the default.
  </para></listitem>
</varlistentry>
</variablelist></para>
options.title: systemd.user.startServices

options.description:
<para>Absolute path to the <command>systemctl</command> tool. This

options.title: systemd.user.systemctlPath

options.description:
<para>Set macOS user defaults. Unlike <option>targets.darwin.defaults</option>,
the preferences will only be applied to the currently logged-in host. This
distinction is important for networked accounts.

Values set to <literal>null</literal> are ignored.

<warning>
  <para>
    Some settings might require a re-login to take effect.
  </para>
</warning></para>
options.type: attribute set of attribute set of anything
options.title: targets.darwin.currentHostDefaults

See <link xlink:href="https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_automatically_starting_applications_on_i3_startup"/>.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.startup

options.description: <para>Whether to run command on each sway restart.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.startup.*.always

options.description: <para>Command that will be executed on startup.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.startup.*.command

options.description: <para>Default terminal to run.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.terminal

options.description: <para>Home row direction key for moving up.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.up

options.description: <para>Window titlebar and border settings.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window

options.description: <para>Window border width.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.border

options.description:
<para>List of commands that should be executed on specific windows.
See <option>for_window</option> swaywm option documentation.</para>

options.description: <para>Swaywm command to execute.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.commands.*.command

options.description:
<para>Criteria of the windows on which command should be executed.
</para><para>
A value of <literal>true</literal> is equivalent to using an empty
criteria (which is different from an empty string criteria).</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.commands.*.criteria

options.description: <para>Hide window borders adjacent to the screen edges.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.hideEdgeBorders

options.default:
''
  true for state version ≥ 23.05
  false for state version < 23.05
''
options.description: <para>Whether to show window titlebars.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.window.titlebar

options.description:
<para>Assume you are on workspace "1: www" and switch to "2: IM" using
mod+2 because somebody sent you a message. You don’t need to remember
where you came from now, you can just press $mod+2 again to switch
back to "1: www".</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.workspaceAutoBackAndForth

options.description:
<para>The mode in which new containers on workspace level will
start.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.workspaceLayout

options.description: <para>Assign workspaces to outputs.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.workspaceOutputAssign

options.description:
<para>Name of the output from <command>
  swaymsg -t get_outputs
</command>.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.workspaceOutputAssign.*.output

options.description: <para>Name of the workspace to assign.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.config.workspaceOutputAssign.*.workspace

options.description: <para>Extra configuration lines to add to ~/.config/sway/config.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.extraConfig

options.description: <para>Like extraConfig, except lines are added to ~/.config/sway/config before all other configuration.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.extraConfigEarly

options.description:
<para>Command line arguments passed to launch Sway. Please DO NOT report
issues if you use an unsupported GPU (proprietary drivers).</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.extraOptions

options.description: <para>Shell commands executed just before Sway is started.</para>
options.example:
''
  export SDL_VIDEODRIVER=wayland
  # needs qt5.qtwayland in systemPackages
  export QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland
  export QT_WAYLAND_DISABLE_WINDOWDECORATION="1"
  # Fix for some Java AWT applications (e.g. Android Studio),
  # use this if they aren't displayed properly:
  export _JAVA_AWT_WM_NONREPARENTING=1
''
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.extraSessionCommands

options.description: <para>Whether to enable configuration of swaynag, a lightweight error bar for sway.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.swaynag.enable

options.description:
<para>Configuration written to
<filename>$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/swaynag/config</filename>.
</para><para>
See
<citerefentry>
  <refentrytitle>swaynag</refentrytitle>
  <manvolnum>5</manvolnum>
</citerefentry>
for a list of available options and an example configuration.
Note, configurations declared under <literal><config></literal>
will override the default type values of swaynag.</para>
options.type: attribute set of attribute set of (Swaynag config atom (null, bool, int, float, str))
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.swaynag.settings

options.description:
<para>Whether to enable <filename>sway-session.target</filename> on
sway startup. This links to
<filename>graphical-session.target</filename>.
Some important environment variables will be imported to systemd
and dbus user environment before reaching the target, including
<itemizedlist>
  <listitem><para><literal>DISPLAY</literal></para></listitem>
  <listitem><para><literal>WAYLAND_DISPLAY</literal></para></listitem>
  <listitem><para><literal>SWAYSOCK</literal></para></listitem>
  <listitem><para><literal>XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP</literal></para></listitem>
</itemizedlist></para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.systemdIntegration

dbus-run-session to the sway command.</para>

options.description:
<para>Whether to make use of the wrapGAppsHook wrapper to execute sway with required environment
variables for GTK applications.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.wrapperFeatures.gtk

options.description: <para>Enable xwayland, which is needed for the default configuration of sway.</para>
options.title: wayland.windowManager.sway.xwayland

options.description: <para>Whether to enable management of XDG base directories.</para>
options.title: xdg.enable

options.description: <para>Absolute path to directory holding application caches.</para>

options.description:
<para>Attribute set of files to link into the user's XDG
configuration home.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile

options.description:
<para>Whether this file should be generated. This option allows specific
files to be disabled.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.enable

options.description:
<para>Set the execute bit. If <literal>null</literal>, defaults to the mode
of the <varname>source</varname> file or to <literal>false</literal>
for files created through the <varname>text</varname> option.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.executable

options.description:
<para>Shell commands to run when file has changed between
generations. The script will be run
<emphasis>after</emphasis> the new files have been linked
into place.
</para><para>
Note, this code is always run when <literal>recursive</literal> is
enabled.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.onChange

options.description:
<para>If the file source is a directory, then this option
determines whether the directory should be recursively
linked to the target location. This option has no effect
if the source is a file.
</para><para>
If <literal>false</literal> (the default) then the target
will be a symbolic link to the source directory. If
<literal>true</literal> then the target will be a
directory structure matching the source's but whose leafs
are symbolic links to the files of the source directory.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.recursive

options.description:
<para>Path of the source file or directory. If
<xref linkend="opt-xdg.configFile._name_.text"/>
is non-null then this option will automatically point to a file
containing that text.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.source

options.description: <para>Path to target file relative to <varname>xdg.configHome</varname>.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.target

options.description:
<para>Text of the file. If this option is null then
<xref linkend="opt-xdg.configFile._name_.source"/>
must be set.</para>
options.title: xdg.configFile.<name>.text

options.description: <para>Absolute path to directory holding application configurations.</para>
options.title: xdg.configHome

options.description:
<para>Attribute set of files to link into the user's XDG

options.title: xdg.dataFile.<name>.executable

options.description:
<para>Shell commands to run when file has changed between

</para><para>
Note, this code is always run when <literal>recursive</literal> is

options.title: xdg.dataFile.<name>.onChange

options.description:
<para>If the file source is a directory, then this option

</para><para>

options.description:
<para>Desktop Entries allow applications to be shown in your desktop environment's app launcher. </para><para>
You can define entries for programs without entries or override existing entries. </para><para>
See <link xlink:href="https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/desktop-entry-spec-latest.html#recognized-keys" /> for more information on options.</para>

This can be useful to e.g. associate this application with MIME types.</para>

options.description: <para>If true, the application prefers to be run on a more powerful discrete GPU if available.</para>

This may override other values.</para>

options.description:

message when started with the <literal>DESKTOP_STARTUP_ID</literal>
environment variable set. If false, it is KNOWN that the application
does not work with startup notification at all.</para>
options.title: xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.startupNotify

options.description: <para>Whether the program runs in a terminal window.</para>
options.title: xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.terminal

options.description: <para>The type of the desktop entry.</para>
options.title: xdg.desktopEntries.<name>.type

options.default: true if host platform is Linux, false otherwise
options.description:
<para>Whether to install programs and files to support the
XDG Shared MIME-info specification and XDG MIME Applications
specification at
<link xlink:href="https://specifications.freedesktop.org/shared-mime-info-spec/shared-mime-info-spec-latest.html"/>
and
<link xlink:href="https://specifications.freedesktop.org/mime-apps-spec/mime-apps-spec-latest.html"/>,
respectively.</para>

<para>Defines additional associations of applications with

<para>The default application to be used for a given mimetype. This

the list is attempted, and so on.</para>

options.description: X server resources that should be set. Booleans are formatted as "true" or "false" respectively. List elements are recursively formatted as a string and joined by commas. All other values are directly formatted using builtins.toString. Note, that 2-dimensional lists are not supported and specifying one will throw an exception. If this and all other xresources options are null, then this feature is disabled and no ~/.Xresources link is produced.
options.type: null or (attribute set of (boolean or signed integer or string or list of (boolean or signed integer or string)))

<para>If set to <literal>true</literal>, desktops configured in <option>monitors</option> will be reset
every time the config is run.

If set to <literal>false</literal>, desktops will only be configured the first time the config is run.
This is useful if you want to dynamically add desktops and you don't want them to be destroyed if you
re-run <literal>bspwmrc</literal>.</para>

options.description:
<para>Bar color settings. All color classes can be specified using submodules
with 'border', 'background', 'text', fields and RGB color hex-codes as values.
See default values for the reference.
Note that 'background', 'status', and 'separator' parameters take a single RGB value.

See <link xlink:href="https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_colors"/>.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*.colors

options.default: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise
options.description: <para>Border, background and text color for a workspace button when the workspace is active.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*.colors.activeWorkspace

options.default: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise

options.default: null for state version ≥ 20.09, as example otherwise
options.description: <para>Border, background and text color for the binding mode indicator</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*.colors.bindingMode

options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.bars.*.colors.focusedSeparator

options.description:
<para>Color settings. All color classes can be specified using submodules
with 'border', 'background', 'text', 'indicator' and 'childBorder' fields
and RGB color hex-codes as values. See default values for the reference.
Note that 'i3.config.colors.background' parameter takes a single RGB value.

See <link xlink:href="https://i3wm.org/docs/userguide.html#_changing_colors"/>.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors

options.description:
<para>Background color of the window. Only applications which do not cover
the whole area expose the color.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors.background

options.description: <para>A window which currently has the focus.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors.focused

options.description:
<para>A window which is the focused one of its container,
but it does not have the focus at the moment.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors.focusedInactive

options.description:

options.description: <para>A window which is not focused.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors.unfocused

options.description: <para>A window which has its urgency hint activated.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.i3.config.colors.urgent

options.description: <para>Whether to enable xmonad window manager.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.xmonad.enable

options.description: <para>Enable xmonad-{contrib,extras} in xmonad.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.xmonad.enableContribAndExtras

options.description:
<para>The configuration file to be used for xmonad. This must be
an absolute path or <literal>null</literal> in which case
<filename>~/.xmonad/xmonad.hs</filename> will not be managed
by Home Manager.
</para>
<para>
If this option is set to a non-<literal>null</literal> value,
recompilation of xmonad outside of Home Manager (e.g. via
<command>xmonad --recompile</command>) will fail.</para>
options.example:
pkgs.writeText "xmonad.hs" ''
  import XMonad
  main = xmonad defaultConfig
      { terminal    = "urxvt"
      , modMask     = mod4Mask
      , borderWidth = 3
      }
''
options.title: xsession.windowManager.xmonad.config

options.description:
<para>Extra packages available to GHC when rebuilding xmonad. The
value must be a function which receives the attribute set
defined in <varname>haskellPackages</varname> as the sole
argument.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.xmonad.extraPackages

options.description:
<para>The <varname>haskellPackages</varname> used to build xmonad
and other packages. This can be used to change the GHC
version used to build xmonad and the packages listed in
<varname>extraPackages</varname>.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.xmonad.haskellPackages

options.description:
<para>Additional files that will be saved in
<filename>~/.xmonad/lib/</filename> and included in the configuration
build. The keys are the file names while the values are paths to the
contents of the files.</para>
options.title: xsession.windowManager.xmonad.libFiles
